awd_titl_txt: Spectrally and Temporally Engineered Processing using PhotoElectroChemistry (STEP-PEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract: 
Non-Technical: Semiconductor devices are ubiquitous. They represent a multi-trillion dollar industry. Ordinary objects such as electrical outlets, thermostats, and blood pressure/heart rate monitors, are being embedded with increasingly complex control electronics, sensors, and network connectivity to enable greater functionality, value, and service. Although foundry services exist for large volume manufacturing of microelectronics for ?smart? objects, there are no cheap (<$100/run) rapid turnaround (<1hr) options for garage inventors to prototype new ideas. The biggest hurdles are that conventional microfabrication requires a cleanroom and expensive (>$1M) equipment. This NSF project seeks to democratize semiconductor manufacturing by investigating a new fabrication paradigm in which pulses of light of specific colors catalyze electrochemical reactions that dope, etch, and metallize designated circuit patterns onto a semiconductor wafer with high resolution. The project offers rich opportunities for high school and community college teachers to participate in research and develop teaching modules for hands-on labs through Research Experiences for Teachers projects. Research and teaching will be integrated through the PI?s ?Principles of Experimental Research? course. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in semiconductor micro- and nano-fabrication, photonics, optical system design, fluid mechanics, and bio-sensors through the proposed research activities. Recruitment, retention, and participation of students from underrepresented groups will be addressed through Research Experiences for Undergraduates internships and engineering summer camps for 9th-12th grade girls. Results from both research and teaching will be widely disseminated in journals and conferences to enhance the current understanding of photoelectrochemical processing and of engineering education/outreach methodologies.
Technical: Photochemical etching uses light to generate minority carriers that catalyze semiconductor wet etching. Recently, the PI?s team implemented photochemical etching using a projector. The local etch rate was controlled using color images drawn in PowerPointTM. Here, the team seeks to drastically improve the etch resolution and anisotropy and expand the method to enable new types of light controlled processes, e.g. patterned doping and metallization, so that new classes of unconventional photonic devices and multifunctional integrated circuits can be fabricated in a single system. In the proposed system, a super-continuum laser, tunable filter, and spatial light modulator will generate high intensity spectrally engineered dynamic image pulses and a synchronized electrical pulse generator will temporally gate the chemical reactions. If successful, this project is potentially transformative because it could create a new semiconductor fabrication paradigm for several reasons. First, multiple processing steps, e.g. doping, etching, and metallization can be performed sequentially in the same system. Second, these processes can be easily aligned to features made through conventional cleanroom processing since the illumination pattern can be adjusted in software. Moreover, this dynamic illumination capability enables new designs to be rapidly prototyped. Next, the processing rate for different bandgap materials can be individually adjusted. Finally, the limitations imposed by conventional planar fabrication technology can be removed and complex 3D devices can be fabricated with precisely controlled dimensions. The overall research goals of this project are to:
1.	Understand how spectral and temporal gating affects the resolution, anisotropy, photo-induced selectivity (e.g. light on vs. off), and material selectivity (e.g. GaAs vs. AlGaAs) of the etch;
2.	Develop photo-induced electroplating and doping techniques; and
3.	Fabricate unconventional devices with complex topography.

Abstract

 

We investigated photochemical etching and used it to demonstrate anisotropic wet etching and to fabricate several devices: 1) grating-coupled plasmonic sensors, 2) parabolic mirrors for enhanced photodetection, 3) vertically tapered waveguides, and 4) master molds for microfluidic devices. We studied and optimized the process parameters for etch selectivity and etch quality.  We also developed insights into the photochemical etch process of n-type GaAs and explained why it can produce micron-sized octahedral crystals under specific conditions.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Using highly diluted etchants, we achieved photochemical etch rates on the order of nanometers per second. The photochemical etching process began with illuminating a substrate that was submerged in an etchant with a projected light image. This accelerated the etch process by generating additional carriers that were utilized during chemical reactions. When etching silicon (Si), we used a potassium hydroxide (KOH) etchant. For gallium arsenide (GaAs), we examined various etchants, including phosphoric, hydrochloric, and citric acid with and without an oxidizer. We determined that an oxidizing agent was necessary for smooth etches. Although light accelerated etching for both p-type Si and n-type GaAs, we observed that light hindered etching for p-type GaAs.

 

While fabricating devices, we discovered that in addition to etchant composition, the color and intensity of the projected light and the size of the projected structures significantly influenced the etch rate. Smaller dimensions etched faster than larger ones. We attribute this to the diffusion-limited nature of etching. We determined that we could alter the diffusion of etchant molecules by illuminating different portions of the substrate at different times.

 

For rapid etching of n-type GaAs, we discovered a new phenomenon occurring on the surface: the growth of micron-sized octahedral crystals composed of arsenic oxide. We studied the different factors that affect the formation of these octahedral crystals such as the etch rate, time, area of illumination, acid type, and substrate quality. Crystals only formed in illuminated regions, as evidenced by a time-lapse video demonstrating crystal formation over time. The results were published in "Selective area formation of arsenic oxide-rich octahedral microcrystals during photochemical etching of n-type GaAs."

 

We explored photo-electrochemical etching of p-type Si. We etched silicon using projector light and low frequency electrical pulsing. The etch rate was surprisingly independent of the pulse?s duty cycle, frequency, and amplitude, and the base concentration. The rate solely depended on the number of pulses and had a linear relationship; thus the etch depth could be controlled electrically.

 

 

We demonstrated anisotropic wet etching by photochemically etching trenches in n-type GaAs to depths that far exceed the carrier diffusion length. We observed that the deeper one etches, the more anisotropic the structure becomes. This was clearly seen with an anisotropy close to 1:9.5 for a 38-μm deep trench.

 

When combined with conventional lithography, PC etching enabled fabrication of gratings (1.6-μm pitch) in n-type GaAs. Such structures can serve as a substrate for surface plasmon polariton (SPP) generation when deposited with gold. With photochemical etching, we could spatially vary the grating depth with a single etch step. As another application of grayscale etching combined with photolithography, we etched vertical tapers on conventional waveguides.

 

We etched a grayscale parabolic mirror and integrated them with a metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) photodetector placed at its focus. This enabled a large light collection area with a small photodetector area (useful for low-noise and high-speed). More work is needed to prevent collapse of the MSM photodetector pedestal during deep etching.

 

We etched staircase structures in GaAs to act as a master mold for a microfluidic device based on a Weir-filter design. We improved etch quality and channel-depth uniformity. Heights were non-uniform only in the channel corners instead of throughout the channel. The master mold pattern was successfully transferred to polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), to be used for microfluidic devices.  The device still requires testing.  

 

Broader Impacts

 

We trained 4 graduates, 7 undergraduates, 1 postdoc and 3 teachers, resulting in 2 MS and 1 BS theses, and partially contributing to 1 completed PhD thesis and 2 in-progress PhD theses. Students learned skills like device design, fabrication, simulations and testing. They developed skills in experimental design because of the large number of parameters involved in this research. They developed skills in solid-state physics, explaining carrier dynamics at semiconductor/electrolyte interfaces with band diagrams. They developed oral and written skills by disseminating results in 1 journal, 3 conference presentations, and 1 patent. The PI integrated some project research into two elective courses: the senior/graduate level ECE446: "Principles of Experimental Research" and the sophomore/junior level ECE304: "Photonic Devices." To promote diversity and inclusion in engineering, the PI and his graduate and undergraduate assistants created and offered four different outreach programs: the Girls Learning Electrical Engineering camp (188 students participated 2010-2019), Illinois Summer Academy (165 students participated 2012-2019), ICANEXSEL (12 students participated in 2017), and I-STEM (22 student-athletes participated in 2017).
